newsitem.title: USA: FOCUS - NYMEX gasoline cracks narrow to 2-year low.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS - NYMEX gasoline cracks narrow to 2-year low.

text.p: As crude rises on U.S.-Iraq tension and heating oil prices continue their steep ascent on low distillate stocks, the NYMEX gasoline-to-crude crack has fallen to its narrowest level in two years.
There is no set nadir to a crack spread, so the spread could narrow much further, dealers said.
"I have seen negative heating oil crack spreads," said a trader.
At 1350 EDT/1750 GMT the October gasoline-to-crude crack was $2.62 a barrel, the lowest level since mid-October 1994.

The crack spread is one barometer of a refiner's profitability, reflecting the margin between the refined product and crude. On way for the gasoline crack to widen is for the market to sell crude and buy gasoline.
"Nobody wants to be short crude with this market, but when things (in Iraq) settle the gasoline spread should widen," said Tom Bentz, an analyst with ING Derivatives.
Gasoline's price gains have lagged the rest of the oil complex since the summer holiday travel season, the time when gasoline demand usually peaks, has ended.
However, traders said the crack may widen as refineries prepare for the winter by increasing heating oil production and decreasing gasoline output.

"The gasoline supply picture is fine for now, but it could eventually tighten as refiners go to heating oil," said Victor Yu, vice president of Refco Energy Group. Tightened gasoline stocks would send gasoline prices up.
"The turnaround could save the day," said Gerald Samuels, managing director of ARB Oil, of the effect the change in refinery output schedules could have on the gasoline crack spread.
"Usually it has bounced up after falling to around $2.50," said Samuels.
Dealers said gasoline's price traditionally becomes compelling when the crack spread narrows too much.
A significantly narrowed margin could limit production as profitability decreases, traders said.

However, the NYMEX crack spread represents the margin between West Texas Intermediate and NYMEX reformulated gasoline, and many refiners use other crudes, so the narrowing NYMEX crack may not signal a margin problem for refiners generally, traders said.

The future price direction of the gasoline crack is impacted by the fact that the NYMEX gasoline contract suffers from decreasing liquidity, a result mainly of the confusion which dogged the contract in the wake of the switch by some states to tougher environmental rules in late 1994 which required a switch to reformulated gasoline (RFG).
